title: Steelers' Cameron Heyward fined for honoring late father with eye black message
text:
Steelers' Cameron Heyward fined for honoring late father with eye black message Sporting News 18 hrs ago customerservice@sportingnews.com (Kirstie Chiappelli) © Ken Blaze-USA TODAY Sports Nov 24, 2013; Cleveland, OH, USA; Pittsburgh Steelers defensive end Cameron Heyward (97) against the Cleveland Browns at FirstEnergy Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Ken Blaze-USA TODAY Sports The NFL and its teams sport pink to raise breast cancer awareness throughout October. But Cameron Heyward is dealing with some questionable repercussions for showing his support.
AdChoices The Steelers defensive end was fined Wednesday for displaying the message "Iron Head" on his eye black in Monday's game against the Chargers as a tribute to his father Craig "Ironhead" Heyward, who played 11 seasons in the NFL as a fullback but died of bone cancer at the young age of 39. Cameron was only 17 at the time of his passing.
CASH: DeAngelo Williams' stiff-arm by NFL unncessary | NFL making strides on domestic violence
Got fined for honoring my Dad who bravely fought cancer on my eye black. #Nevergiveup #CancerSucks pic.twitter.com/RTx988ijG9
— Cam Heyward (@CamHeyward) October 14, 2015
According to NFL Network , Heyward has been fined $5,787 for the display, which is the standard fine for the first violation of the league's uniform policy against "personal messages."
Heyward's fine comes one day after it was reported the league refused to allow his teammate, running back DeAngelo Williams, to wear pink all season to honor his mother, who died of breast cancer last year, and further support awareness of the disease. His mother's four sisters also fought breast cancer and all died from the disease by 2011.
The controversial rulings will only fuel criticism toward the league's notoriously strict uniform policies and "Pink October" campaign.
